data.title: The Perils of Community as a Construct for the Political Ideology of Welsh Nationalism
data.meta_description: The Perils of Community as a Construct for the Political Ideology of Welsh Nationalism - Volume 33 Issue 4
data.text:
THIS ARTICLE EXPLORES THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE CONCEPT of community and the incremental construction of a political ideology for Plaid Cymru, the Welsh nationalist party. In explaining the two general applications of community, empirical and evaluative, the article claims that there is an essential vagueness attached to community which limits its value in developing a clear ideological focus for a political party. This incoherence within the concept, coupled with a specific reluctance to analyse and apply community more precisely within the framework of Welsh nationalism, has made it more a hindrance than an asset to Plaid Cymru's political and electoral progress.

1 See, for example Davies, D. H., The Welsh Nationalist Party 1925–1945: A Call to Nationhood, Cardiff, University of Wales Press, 1983 Google Scholar; Evans, G., Fighting for Wales, Talybont Y Lolfa, 1991 Google Scholar; Williams, E. W., The Politics of Welsh Home Rule 1886–1929, A Sociological Analysis, PhD thesis, University of Wales, 1986 Google Scholar; Thomas, C., The Celtic Nations, Celtic League, 1963 Google Scholar; A. Phillip, Butt, The Welsh Question: Nationalism in Welsh Politics 1945–1970, Cardiff, University of Wales Press, 1975 Google Scholar.
